block.p: Nicholas D. Kristof's endorsement of nuclear power as a less risky choice than fossil fuels for America's energy future makes sense if three conditions can be met.
Nicholas D. Kristof's endorsement of nuclear power as a less risky choice than fossil fuels for America's energy future makes sense if three conditions can be met.

First, the public must believe that nuclear power generation can be safely regulated. An editorial the same day about the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's failure to acknowledge safety concerns at existing reactor pools (''Terrorist Attacks on Reactor Pools'') only deepens distrust.

Second, for the nuclear option to be seriously considered, a site for a secure waste facility must be in place and safe waste transportation ensured. The development of a Nevada waste site has faced unparalleled opposition for years.
And third, nuclear energy can be pursued only as part of an overall energy policy of conservation, efficiency and alternative-generation fuels and methods.
The writer is an environmental consultant.
